## 1 . Granularity â†’ **â€œIdea chunks + evidence pointersâ€**

* **Storage unit = Idea Chunk**  
  *Roughly a paragraph or coherent turn in chat.*  
  Each chunk becomes one **`Statement`** node whose text is stored verbatim.  
* **Evidence pointer**: a `HAS_SOURCE_SENTENCE` edge back to the **exact sentence** (kept only for provenance, not exploded into the main graph).  
* **Benefit** â€“ keeps the core graph small while letting you drill down for justification when youâ€™re reviewing an extraction. îˆ€citeîˆ‚turn0search1îˆ‚turn0search0îˆ

## 2 . Core ontology â†’ **E-A-R spine + PROV-O for meta-data**

| Layer | Purpose | Key classes / properties |
|-------|---------|--------------------------|
| **Spine (Entity-Attribute-Relation)** | Carries â€œwhat you talked about.â€ | `Concept`, `Person`, `Project`, `Goal`, `Value`, `Belief`, `Task`, `Question`, `Experience` |
| **Linguistic layer** | Connects raw words â†’ ideas. | `Statement` (holds the chunk) â†’ `MENTIONS` â†’ any spine node |
| **Conflict layer** | Records tensions without collapsing them. | `SUPPORTS`, `CONTRADICTS`, `REFINES`, `UNRESOLVED_WITH` |
| **Provenance layer (W3C PROV-O)** | Who said what, when, in which lens. | `wasAttributedTo`, `generatedAtTime`, `wasDerivedFrom`, `hadPrimarySource` |

Using PROV-O saves you reinventing trust & traceability; recent work shows it mates cleanly with domain ontologies and even BFO if you ever need stricter upper-level semantics. îˆ€citeîˆ‚turn0search4îˆ‚turn0search9îˆ

## 3 . Extraction pipeline (minimal viable)

1. **Chunker** â€“ splits long chats into idea-sized turns.  
2. **Grammar pass** â€“ NER + â€œconcept spottingâ€ (noun-phrase â†’ `Concept`).  
3. **Logic pass** â€“ Argument-component tagging (claim, premise, counter-premise) using the 2024 ArgMining models; edges become `SUPPORTS`/`CONTRADICTS`. îˆ€citeîˆ‚turn0search1îˆ  
4. **Rhetoric pass** â€“ LIWC-style motive & sentiment tags; maps to `Value` or `Goal`.  
5. **Lens annotator** â€“ A rule set that marks each statement with the lens(es) it naturally fits (Edelman, Taylor, etc.) so you can slice the same graph multiple ways.  

Everything above can be prototyped with off-the-shelf Python + spaCy/transformers, then written into Neo4j or TerminusDB.
